name: NPR
text: At least 71 nations have already imposed limitations or full bans on exports of essential COVID-19 supplies ‚Äî forcing many of the poorest countries into bidding wars over highly urgent, highly priced medical products. https://t.co/9WhrEKC60o

name: NPR
text:
From the adoption of a teenage daughter to the birth of a baby boy, here are a few of the best things that happened to @NPRItsBeenAMin listeners this week.

Check out the podcast at https://t.co/uq1X48zQdp. https://t.co/2YuA4kGMga

name: NPR
text:
Stephania Ergemlidze has been bringing a portable basketball hoop to protests. 

"Obviously, basketball is not going to solve the problem," she says. "We were more looking towards trying to ease the tension ... that way, maybe messages can get across." https://t.co/P3bwgH0Wsc

name: NPR
text: "I don't necessarily agree with defunding police," says Memphis Police Association President Michael Williams, but he agrees "whole-heartedly" that the city's budget isn't equitably spread to address the needs of the people of Memphis. https://t.co/zvjVUy02SR

name: NPR
text:
Author Liara Tamani: "Even when things seem to be going terrible in the world .... I want teens to remember to look to the blue sky for peace. To listen to the birds and pay attention to the trees. Simple things, but they can be transcendent."
https://t.co/zJPgPlrZ5R

name: NPR
text: Polish soldiers mistakenly crossed the border into the Czech Republic and stopped people on the wrong side. Both co‚Ä¶ https://t.co/LF9fJBHE7o

name: NPR
text:
The Democratic Republic of the Congo spends $19 per citizen on health care annually. 

In the U.S., the number is nearly $10,000. 

While experts warn that higher health spending doesn't necessarily lead to better outcomes, it helps in a pandemic. https://t.co/zLIarJjYsL

name: NPR
text:
Ella Jones, who will be the first black and first female mayor of Ferguson, Mo., says the city has seen widespread reforms since the police killing of Michael Brown. But it still needs to "strive toward a better image."
https://t.co/oIBB3IVTwx

name: NPR
text:
The Trump administration has proposed new rules that would sharply restrict how asylum is granted to immigrants seeking protection in the U.S.

Critics say the rules are so severe they would effectively shut down the U.S. asylum system.
https://t.co/oyMG9jxArT

name: NPR
text: Ashima Shiraishi has won rock climbing championships, set records ‚Äî and done it all before the age of 20. So @waitwait invited her to play a game called "Let's take the easy way up" ‚Äî 3 questions about escalators. https://t.co/r36fBmFEqh

name: NPR
text:
Paleontologist Nizar Ibrahim and his team discovered the first-known swimming dinosaur, the Spinosaurus. Their findings were detailed in "Nature" earlier this year.

 üéß Hear him talk about it on #NPRShortWave: https://t.co/htHGln2J4I

name: NPR
text: Reality show ‚ÄòCops‚Äô was canceled recently, amid criticisms of police depictions in popular culture. NPR film critic Eric Deggans says it's part of a larger issue, Deggans speaks with host Sam Sanders on a new episode of @NPRItsBeenaMin. https://t.co/Dn3lf1i9av https://t.co/8zxI4yOjpM

name: NPR
text: In a new, scrupulously reported biography, reporter Mary Jordan writes that Melania Trump used the fact that her husband needed her public loyalty after he was accused of infidelity and assault to negotiate a better prenup. https://t.co/FdCQxo3Lfo

name: NPR
text:
Young people were more politically active in 2018 compared to 2016*:

‚Ä¢ 48% signed a petition (2016 - 34%)
‚Ä¢ 15% attended a demonstration (2016 - 5%)
‚Ä¢ 23% followed a candidate on social media (2016 - 16%)

*according to data from Tufts University
https://t.co/r92c4bMU7o

name: NPR
text:
Research suggests protest energy could boost youth voter turnout: Young people aligned with the Parkland gun control movement were 21% more likely to vote in 2018, according to researchers at Tufts University. 
https://t.co/ODkLOh7xEP

name: NPR
text:
California is paying to train 20,000 new contact tracers by July. Many of these recruits are librarians, who are an obvious choice for the job: 

They're curious, tech-savvy ‚Äî and great at getting strangers to open up. https://t.co/3sEAtYoBLw

name: NPR
text:
Here's how racial inequity affects U.S. school children, including:

‚Ä¢ Black students are more likely to be arrested at school
‚Ä¢ Black students are more likely to be suspended
‚Ä¢ White school districts get more funding on average than nonwhite ones https://t.co/cBVqTAERZL

name: NPR
text: Swarms of locusts are descending ravenously on the Horn of Africa ‚Äî and posing a major threat to food security. A swarm of just 1 square kilometer can consume as much food as would be eaten by 35,000 people in a single day. https://t.co/UZdPn0pKgY

name: NPR
text:
ICYMI: Boston Mayor Marty Walsh has declared racism a public health crisis.

He will reallocate $3 million from the city's police department to public health ‚Äî and will propose transferring $9 million more for housing and counseling initiatives.
https://t.co/LF2lXbUHQA

name: NPR
text: ICYMI: The Trump administration on Friday finalized a rule that would remove nondiscrimination protections for LGBTQ people in health care and health insurance. https://t.co/KU30dTl4bM

name: NPR
text:
Rep. Denver Riggleman has lost the GOP nomination for his central Virginia seat to challenger Bob Good ‚Äì a former Liberty University official who has said he's on a mission to return Judeo-Christian values to Washington.
https://t.co/5CTxRkLobC

name: NPR
text:
"The death of George Floyd has a strong echo in the death ... of my little brother," said the sister of Adama Traor√©, a black man who died in police custody in 2016.

"What's happening in the United States is happening in France. Our brothers are dying." https://t.co/P0g104Efk1

name: NPR
text:
The definition of racism will get an update in Merriam-Webster.

The move comes after recent college grad Kennedy Mitchum emailed its editors and suggested that the definition should include a reference to systemic oppression. @hereandnow
https://t.co/x4XLMIEhiE
